reviewText:
Before Halo, Call of Duty, and other new-school shooters that currently saturate the FPS market, there was the old school. I’m talking about games that kept the same spirit as Wolfenstein 3D, like the Doom series, Duke Nukem 3D, Half-Life, the Quake series, and Unreal. If you lived through this time, you know what I’m talking about. These games are representative of a peak in shooters in that their challenge, length, and fun depended on gameplay alone—no cutscenes that pad the game time, no predictable plot elements, and no exploitative glitches that most new school gamers use in games today. Controls were fluid and customizable, combat was fast and furious, and the games were almost exclusively for PC. It took skill to play and if you were killed, you had only yourself to blame. This was when multiplayer was on the rise, before mods and cheating took hold to as great an extent as it does now, and before cheap tactics like quick-scoping were often the deciding factor in encounters.

Aliens vs. Predator Classic 2000, as it’s currently known, in some ways represents one of the last examples of this FPS golden age. It was released in 1999 in the wake of the game-changing Quake (1996) and Half-Life (1998). Its main selling point, of course, is that you can play as each of the three different species, the Marine, Predator, and Alien. There are three different campaigns for each, and beating each on successively harder difficulties unlocks up to five bonus levels for each, which also bestow additional equipment to the predator and marine. Additionally, if you complete certain challenges, you can also unlock new options that may classify as “cheats” in single player. You won’t really see much of a storyline progression between levels because there isn’t really a story. As with most developers of old school shooters, Rebellion focused on gameplay more than anything and the result is excellent.

Being a game now available on Steam, you’re probably thinking about multiplayer, and yes, that is one of the best reasons for this game’s existence. In fact, it seems almost designed as a tournament fighter, given the vast differences between species. If you were to never play the story missions at all, you would still have endless amounts of fun. Of course, I’m referring more to this game in its prime (early 2000’s) rather than now, because as you might expect, not many people still play this game. But when you find a game, you will see that the multiplayer is still very good and holds up today, even if it’s under-populated.

The perfect word to describe this game is balanced. Each species has its own advantages and disadvantages such that you never really feel like one is significantly over- or under-powered. The alien is the fastest, can jump the farthest, and walk on walls, but it’s the weakest physically and only has close-range weapons. The marine is slow and relatively weak, but can resupply through medpacks and armor and has access to the motion tracker and the game’s strongest weapons. The predator is the physically toughest, has strong weapons and cloaking device, but is kind of clunky with its limited energy, limited speargun ammo, and species-specific vision modes.

Now for the gameplay. This game is fast, incredibly fast. Like other old-school shooters, you have to react quickly and precisely or you’ll end up dead. Start spamming your weapons and you’ll just leave yourself open to attack and die. This game can feel relentless but never unfair. As stated above, it’s the product of a more refined and merciless age, before button-mashing, quick-scoping, and button-combinations became as prevalent as they are now. Like the alien itself, this game goes back to the roots of what makes a great shooter by stripping away all the hand-holding.

Need I say more? If you’re a product of the nineties, then you were probably into either the Aliens or Predator series at one point or another. Even if you’re not, this is a great game solely for the gameplay value. And for $4.99 you can’t really go wrong. In my opinion it’s the best AvP game ever released (better than AVP2 and 2010). And honestly, I don’t have any gripes or complaints about it, which is pretty rare for me.

For those of you interested in the more technical aspects, the Steam version is the 2000 update by Rebellion that allows for saving (yes, the original did not allow saves) and has two new weapons, the Skeeter missile launcher and the dual-wielding pistols, both for the marine. You can get graphical updates through what’s called the Redux mod, which you can get at moddb.com. You can also pick up extra multiplayer maps and other refinements for this game there as well. Happy hunting.

reviewText:
Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is an example of how to do First-Person-Shooters right. The fast gameplay requires more skill and focus than most modern First-Person-Shooters. Instead of trying to level up your character to get OP weapons, most weapons have a legitimate purpose, and most of them don't feel too overpowered (except Disc, Pred Pistol, Skeeter, and Sadar. Not to forget Mines). Instead of grinding to get perks to power yourself up, Aliens versus Predator requires skill from the start.

Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 allows the player to take control of three species, Aliens, Predators, or the human Marines. Each have their advantages and disadvantages.

The Alien is a melee only species, a hurtful disadvantage, but is patched up by the speed and wallcrawling ability that the Aliens have. Aliens also can smell the scents of other beings, allowing it to see its victims in the dark. The Alien regains health by headbiting Predators and Humans, you can do this on both the living and the dead. Obviously headbiting live beings is harder than dead ones, but gains back more health.

The Predator is a mix of Melee and ranged weapons. The majority of his weapons, Medicomp, and cloak are powered by 'Field Charge'. This will slowly recharge if you are not using anything that uses charge, or you can find field-charge items around the map which will automatically give you full energy. The only weapons that don't use energy are the Wristblades, and Disc (Unless you use the recall ability, this will use a small amount of energy), as well as the Speargun. But this uses ammo, which only replenishes upon death. The Predator can heal using his Medicomp, this will use a large amount of energy, but puts you back to full health everytime (TIP: The Medicomp's secondary fire can extinguish you if you're on fire). In some of the bonus levels the Predator gains a new gadget, the grappling hook, which can pull him to higher heights. The Predator also has three vision modes, which can help him spot enemies. The first vision mode can help spot humans, the second aliens, and the third other Predators and field-charges (Of course you also have the default normal vision).

The Marine is a ranged only species. The marine uses weapons like the pulse rifle, smartgun, minigun, etc. The Marine replenishes health with medkits, found about through-out levels. The marine can use armor, which can protect against Alien acid and absorbs small amounts of damage. In some of the bonus levels the Marines get a jetpack! In multiplayer Marines can select a specialist sub-class, this will allow them to pick from any of the weapons in the game (unless game host restricted it), and you will always spawn with the selected weapon, but you can only use that weapon (and the pistol).

Each species can unlock bonus missions after you complete the main game, (you will unlock more if you beat it on a higher difficulty) these levels are the levels from other species singleplayer, for example: You can unlock a backwards version of the Predator's first level as Marine if you beat the Marine SP on Director's cut [Hard].

Not to forget, you can unlock cheat options in the game by completing certain objectives through-out the levels. These can be things like slow-mo whenever you are near enemies. Or unlimited speargun ammo and more spears per shot as Predator.

The Multiplayer is where this game shines most. Fast gameplay and the different play-styles of each species make for very fun and memorable experience. This is one of the fastest games ever, you will die, fast, and a lot. It is extremely well balanced, and I almost never feel like a player is winning because of the species they are playing as. But, unfortunately, this game has a small player base, so at times you may not be able to find a game. Because of this the community doesn't play competitively [most of the time], anymore. Servers will also usually have a small amount of players. 8-player games are kinda rare, but when they happen, it's a lot of fun!

Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is easily one of the best games ever made.

I admire its purity."

-MandatoryAlcatraz"

reviewText:
Old, but a supreme classic // A must buy for FPS & series fans
+ Game boasts a second tier of bonus missions, available after completing a given campaign; these are fun and do well to increase replayability
+ Each of the three species is completely unique in design and feel
+ Sound effects are all ripped striaght from their respective films, and are sure to delight fans
+ Runs astonishingly well on newer systems, and there are no compatibility issues that have made themselves apparent
+ Everything in the game, from the weapons to the set designs, is faithful to the series
+ Combat, item interaction, and movement are all crisp, simple, and polished
+ The game absolutely drips with atmosphere, particularly during the Marine's campaign
+ Allows one to connect to players playing the game through both Steam and GoG; this is excellent, and much needed, as the few players that still occasion the game's multiplayer seem to be doing so through GoG
+ When available, multiplayer is fast-paced and ferocious; it's great fun, and has a vintage feel to it

- Classes feel a bit unbalanced in multiplayer, though not crushingly so (Predator appears to have the advantage, followed by Alien and Marines, in that order)
- No autosave function; while it's good that a save function has been added at all from the original, the saves are limited per mission, and if one forgets to save, this could lead to lots of frustrated backtracking from the level's beginning
- Stock campaigns are painfully short; all 15 campaign missions (not including bonus levels) can be wrapped up in around 5 hours without a walkthrough
- Visuals have certainly not aged well, in any way (though there are apparently some mods available that can remedy this to a certain extent)
- No clear map or objective markers available; one can easily get turned around

reviewText:
One of the best games of the late 90's and early 00's. AvP combines three unique playstyles in three full length campaigns.
The missions will take you to different locations in the AvP universe, some of them taken from the films, some brand new. The general pacing and atmosphere is somewhat unique as enemy attacks and appearances are for the large part unscripted, and can change between playthroughs, which causes a sense of suspense as each play is a bit different. The level design is solid, item pickups are strategically placed so careful resoruce management is vital for survival. The combat is usually resolved at a break-neck speed, this combined with the dark design of the levels and a meager health supply can cause panic and a genuine sense of fear.

Multiplayer is crazy fun, albeit somewhat unbalanced. While the campaigns are tailored to each race specifically the multiplayer just sort of mashes the three races together giving them some balance problems. Some weapons are too effective and essentially overpowered while some are useless completely. Fortunately weapons can be removed during the game setup eliminating some issues. Despite these objections, multiplayer is excellent in some aspects like, for example, some maps featuring destructible lighting as a tactical aid, wave style co-op mode and some interesting alternative play styles.

The marine campaign and gameplay should be familiar to all FPS players, marines are the weakest and slowest of the trio but they make up for it with bristling firepower. Marine campaign is the most atmospheric and genuinely frightening of the three, walking around dark instalations, fending off waves of drones and facehuggers evading predators and generally surviving by the skin of your teeth.
Predator campaign puts you in the shoes of a cold blooded space hunter, using a combination of melee weapons and high tech gadgets and devices to hunt your prey. Predators are the most beefy of the three able to shrug off alien claws and marine gunfire alike, however stealth and careful planning are paramount to a successful hunt. Predator campaign revolves around the hunt, from humans to exotic forms of the xenomorph.
The alien is a terrifying killing machine. It can climb walls, cover 30 meters in a single pounce, smell its prey and destroy it with a combination of razor sharp claws, barbed tail or a powerful inner jaw. Since it posseses no ranged weapons the alien must stalk it's prey (not unlike the predator), isolate it and destroy it.

reviewText:
Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is an absolutely excellent game.

This game (On normal mode) Is very challenging on all three species to play with. I personally enjoy the Marine missions the most, due to the terrifying atmosphere and fast, tight, and frantic First-Person-Shooter gameplay. This game doesn't rely on simple  jumpscares to be a scary game... it has real atmosphere. The Aliens are so smart and every time I hear one of their famous screeches... (nearby or far from me) I frantically spin around and search all over. (And believe me... when you turn around and unsuspectingly find an Alien behind you... it's a real treat. You'll fire your pulse rifle with such intensity... This game just really draws you in. If you (Like I was at first) are nervous about the game being too scary, just know that it still is a brilliant blend between an Action Packed First-Person-Shooter that even a real scaredy-cat like me can  enjoy this game thoroughly.

The other campaigns are... you guessed it, GREAT.

The Alien missions are all centered on some stealth and puzzle solving, and you will move at near BLINDING speeds, taking out anything that stands between you and the end of the level. I love being able to attack in a variety of ways, including lashing out your tail or slashing at your enemies with a swift scratch from your claws. The multiplayer with Aliens only is incredible. It gets really competitive as you dash toward your enemies... instincts set to kill. It feels awesome to overpower every marine (Or Predator for that matter) with the Xenomorph class.

The third campaign, focused on the Predator is very focused on stealth (Turning invisible, sneaking up behind enemies, etc.) You have many ways to attack your enemies. This campaign is pretty great, you will feel very overpowered as you hack through your enemies. There are many fun to use gadgets to take out your enemies, and you can zoom in and snipe or just go all out close combat with your opponents. This class is really awesome to play with during multiplayer, always silent but deadly as the Predator class.

This game really nails it's atmosphere, despite the somewhat dated graphics (Hey, it's from 1999-2000!) The sound is excellent and the dramatic music comes at just the right time to keep the game tense. This game was great for it's time... and still remains a classic that any fan of Aliens (Or any newcomers to the franchise) MUST pick up. At a very affordable price point of $4.99 this game offers so much, including Campaigns, Multiplayer, Survival Mode, and hours and hours of pure ALIEN FUN! I enthusiastically recommend this game.

Now... I need to get back to work on fighting off hordes of Aliens...

reviewText: It's been more than ten years since I last touched this game and I'm glad to notice it hasn't aged much; in fact, it's still clearly better than Colonial Marines. The game's map design seems bland at times in terms of details but the game relies so much on lighting and ambient sounds that often you don't even notice the blocky design. All three species are well represented: The Marine is a weakling facing overwhelming odds, the Predator a seasoned (but slow) veteran capable of one-hit killing Xenomorphs with his wristblades, and the Xenomorph (Alien) opens up routes beyond the reaches of humans & predators. The game's incredible speed may disorient at first but it really fits and makes the game more intense. One thing I particularly liked is how in those Marine & Predator maps where you face aliens you can never rely on being absolutely safe; waste too much time doing nothing and more aliens will spawn to come and get you. The game has its drawbacks such as its often confusing map layouts, especially in some of the Alien campaign maps, and the lack of a relevant story, but these are rather minor issues. Beaware; the game is harder on normal than the vast majority of games are on hard, and it's only made harder by the limited number of saves (four on normal) you get per level.

The old Aliens vs. Predator is one of games you remember. It was a game that broke the standard FPS mold and gave us a unique and innovative experience.

The basic game is broken up into three unique campaigns, played from the different viewpoints of a Marine, a Xenomorph and a Predator. Each one with it's own unique perspective and abilities. The Marine plays much like your standard survival shooter. You walk down big empty corridors with your heart jumping out of your chest every time the motion sensor beeps. The Predator is like a beefed up marine with better weapons and the different vision modes we all remember from the movies. The alien gameplay however is where the game really shines. All of the sudden there is no up and down. No left and right. Everything is open when the maps become a myriad of ventilation shafts and shortcuts allowing you to sneak up on your unsuspecting prey. Nothing is linear when you can climb on the ceiling.

A great game, even by today's standards.

reviewText:
Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is one of my all-time favorite first person shooters. It does tremendous justice to the source material upon which it is based and is one of the finest examples of an excellent game based around movie licenses.

The alien, predator, and marne campaigns all play very differently from one another. The strengths and weaknesses peculiar to each species really make the online multiplayer experience something special, although predators and marines do move absurdly fast during deathmatches. It seems like the developer was trying to balance movement between the species, but doing this by artificially speeding up marines and predators to move as quickly as aliens just seems wrong. Movement speeds are normal in skirmish matches, which I prefer to deathmatches.

Although AVP's online netcode is peer-to-peer based, it is easily the best impementation of P2P netcode I have ever experienced. In fact, it consistently outperforms dedicated servers for other games - even when I play AVP with players from across the world while stationed in mainland China (which has some of the worst internet anywhere).

There is still an online community for this game, and the regular players tend to be very down to earth and friendly. Unfortunately, you may encounter the odd cheater from time to time, but the Steam port allows you to set up private games with your friends. It would have been better if players were given tools to kick and ban cheaters from their games by way of vote, but considering how well native netcode was incorporated into a game this old, it's hard to complain about that (or the lack of native voicechat.)

As great as the online experience is, it's hard for me to say enough positive things about the single player campaigns. While there is a very minimal sense of plot, you do feel like you have purpose to your actions and that all the carnage the unfolds does so for good reason.

The atmosphere and tension in the game are incredible. When ambushed by aliens, you can easily die a sudden death. Aliens pose a very real threat to the player and do not strike exclusively during scripted sequences (like in the game's sequels). What that means is that you'll need to be on your toes at all times while playing this game. Its hard but fair, and that's the way I like it. AVP has treated me to some of the most startling moments I've ever experienced, and it's nice knowing that I can experience those kinds of moments again and again despite how much time I've spent enjoying the game.

If you're going to play the alien campaign, be aware that the very first stage is probably the most difficult one you'll encounter. That's because is so easy to be nearly burned to death from the moment you encounter the first human carrying a molotov cocktail, and there are many of them throughout the stage. Not only are you very likely to be slowly incinerated by their concoctions if they are thrown anywhere in your general vacinity, but also if you kill a human who happens to be carrying one.

As an alien, it's also very easy to get mowed down by stage 1's automated machine gun turrents unless you can find a way to sneak around them. A viable - but also very challenging - alternative to overcoming those obstacles is to crawl on ceilings and dart past the turrents at a 60 degree angle.

It took me many, many replays before I was finally able to develop a good sense of how to overcome stage 1's cocktail-wielding humans and automated machine gun turrents. Had I known that you can enable unlimited saves by saving a command line in the game's launch options, I could have saved myself a lot of frustrating but strangely fun chalenge while trying to beat the first alien stage.

While doing business abroad, I was able to play AVP perfectly with full settings on a friggin' netbook. Not even the original Doom or Heretic can run on that kind of hardware without occasional slowdown when launched with Zandronum or zDoom.

In conclusion, AVP Classic 2000 is one of the very best puchases I have ever made, even though I owned the retail version of the game prior to buying the Steam port for convenient online multiplayer access. Get this game now, even if there is no discount at the time you are reading this review. The game is worth it, and then some. I tip my hat to Rebellion software for this great game.

MY RATING FOR AVP CLASSIC 2000 (ACROSS VARIOUS KEY FACTORS):

Graphics: 7.5 / 10. They were pretty good at the time of the game's release, and there are moments when the game's visuals still inspire awe, like the waterfall at the end of the predator's first stage.

Sound: 10 / 10.

Single-player content: 10 / 10.

Online experience: 9.5 / 10. The native matchmaking system that was incorporated into the 'Classic 2000' port of the game is very good, and the game's netcode is - in my experience - unparalleled. Even though the netcode is P2P-based, it consistently outperformes many dedicated servers supporting other games. The main reason why the game doesn't get a perfect score in this category is because the absence of dedicated servers means that sometimes you have to wait a while until someone joins an online game that you host for lack of being able to find an online match to connect to. Other than incorporating native voice chat and giving players a voting system for banning cheaters / jerks / etc., there isn't much more that I could ask for from the game's excellent multiplayer component.

Plot: 6 / 10. This is the game's weakest link. There really isn't much of a plot to the game, but there are videos that play on monitors as you progress through the single-player modes. You can ignore the videos if you like, but Rebellion deserves credit for incorporating these clips into the game without slowing it down for those who want to focus on action. To be fair, the game intended to showcase atmosphere over plot and really did a fine job in that regard. (It's like the original Quake, albeit with scripted FMV playback that gives purpose to new challenges you experience.)

Gameplay: 10 / 10. Incredible! Play the game and experience the terror, the suspense, and the frantic action for yourself!

Overall: 88 / 100

reviewText:
A game straight from my childhood. Even my avatar has ties to this game, which used a community called MPlayer for multiplayer. That's not important though.

AVP, AVP Gold, AVP Classic, whatever you call it, this game is what started the AVP multiplayer franchise. It is the original and the best. The single player campaign is not dissimilar to other shooters from the era, where you were given an objective at the beginning of the game and no true waypoints. You are left to explore the area and kill everything that moves. It has several references to the films, including the pilot ship from the original Alien/Aliens movie.

Multiplayer is a different beast. The multiplayer consumed my life for years and began my path to become a gamer. Super fast-paced action across dozens of maps ranging from Species Death Match and Death Match to Cooperative. Each species had its own perks, strengths to overpower your opponents and weaknesses you needed to minimize in order to not die. The whole game was fantastic, with brilliant maps from the Subway mimicing the Predator 2 movie, to the LV-426 complex and the Nostromo from the Alien franchise. Sounds ripped straight from the movies were used in the game making it feel more like the creatures from the movies.

Pros:
Fast-paced action
Simple game modes
Great map designs
Easter eggs which reference the movies from both franchises
Easily played even on old machines
Can disable certain weapons if you don't want them used in Multiplayer
Cons:
Dated game, few players will be present for multiplayer if any at all
May be too fast for modern gamers
Dated graphics (This game was from 2000 after all, not really a true con, but may be a turn off to players)
Almost no story
Depends on local hosts, no servers

Yeeaaaaahhh..... I want to like it. I really do. I love the movies (well, the first ones anyhow), and I got this for free from selling cards, so maybe I shouldn't complain, but I feel like it was a waste even then. Lemme talk it through:

There are three characters to play. Yeah, so far that's the only cool part of this for me. There's the Alien, the Predator, and the human Soldier.

The soldier was the easiest to play. He was the only one that didn't have a bunch of weird and confusing controls and HUD. Not necessarily that he didn't have any work put into him. Actually I think it's good they left him so simple, otherwise he would be just as confusing and/or difficult to play as the others. He's just the basic soldier-y character, and was fun to play for a few minutes.

The Alien is the one you want to immediately jump to playing, naturally. What cooler character to be than an all-powerful alien crawling on ceilings and ripping apart humans. Except he can't. The crawling is hard because of his super-weird, eye-throbbing x-ray but not-x-ray vision. AND, no matter how hard I try, as soon as I'm seen by humans, they start shooting, and I have five seconds to panic, try to fight, and then die. I don't get it. He's more annoying to play than anything.

The Predator. I really, really thought I was going to enjoy being a super-strong, armored alien. But... he's really, really confusing, and hard to play. Now, there's the expected problems, because of the game being a tiny bit older. Jumping can be tricky, and turning and discriminating a black alien from a low-res brown wall can be a pain, but manageable. But then add a weird hieroglyphic power system, a slew of different weird weapons, and did I mention the power system?, all together makes for a mess of a hard-to-play extra-terrestrial.

So yeah, there's the problems with it being a bit old. But it's not that, it's the weird gameplay mechanics, poor design choices, and over-use of things that older games have obvious problems with anyways that really makes this a hard game to enjoy. I think they put more time into making it about three characters than making each character a good one. If it had JUST been the Alien to play, and they put all the effort on the one rather than three different characters, it would've been way better. I actually do kind of like it, but there's just poor choices here.

6/10, 'cause I wanna like it, but still, not Recommended

reviewText:
RATING: 6/10

Aliens Versus Predator: Classic 2000 is exactly how it sounds. It's a reenvisioned version of the first AVP game with an enhanced engine and intuitive combat. The xenomorph and predator designs are beautiful despite the aged graphics.

THE GOOD:
The game does a stellar job of showing off the ferocity of the iconic xenomorphs. However, they don't seem as threateningly intelligent as those in the movies. Most of the time, they simply rush at you heedlessly and are little more than average cannon fodder for those weilding a pulse rifle. Combat controls are responsive and easy to handle, and a wide range of weaponry and attacks are available to each class.

THE BAD:
The bad part is the story, which truly killed it. Although the level design is good, the storyline in itself is horrendous. In fact, I didn't even know what the story was for any of the campaigns. All I know is that some fat guy on the televisions was telling me where to go and what to do, which was basically kill this, kill that, get here and complete the level. Another demoralizng part is the fact that each campaign starts and ends with a beautifully detailed CGI cutscene, but then immediatey transitions into the hideous textures of the actual game. The lack of direction as to what you should do forces players to save constantly, as you will inevitably see many cheap deaths in each campaign. Not even the extra levels beyond the main campaign are very good, as they have little to no dialogue and just give you an extra gun or a jetpack to shoot more xenomorphs. As no one ever plays the multiplayer, I can't say anything for that, and every time I try to play the other game modes, it doesn't load, which is odd considering that I have a very good computer. The part that annoyed me the most, however, was the terrible musical score, which was just annoying and nonsensical.

VERDICT:
If you're a fan of the xenomorphs or the predators, then you may enjoy this game. But if you like story, prepare for frustration, because this game has none. Graphics are hideous in comparison to other games made in this era and the enemy AI are simply stupid and kill you in cheap ways. Overall, you aren't missing anything by not playing this game.

reviewText:
Aliens vs Predator Classic 2000 is a first person shooter with a unique gimmick. There are 3 campaigns starring drastically different characters. You can play as a Marine, Predator, or Alien. Each has their own playstyle  and weaponry.

The game is from 2000, so the graphics are quite dated. People, enemies and environments all look very blocky. Thankfully, the devs have increased the resolution for the rerelease, so everything appears a bit sharper than I imagine it did in the original. Still, the graphics are rough and that's something you will have to deal with if you want to enjoy this game.

Each species has a unique control style, and luckily in this update gamepad support was added. That's my preferred method, although I found the aiming to be quite difficult, and probably much easier to handle with a mouse. There are some areas with generally frustrating platforming which you will have to navigate. You are also just thrown into the campaign without a tutorial, so prepare to learn the controls yourself through trial and error. Most games these days at least let you know quickly how to get around the controls, so this game shows its age in that way.

The sound and general atmosphere is pretty well done. There is voice acting, and as a marine you will get your orders from the recording of a live actor. There are some general scary moments, especially playing as a marine in the dark while Xenomorphs are hunting you.

Overall, while I feel this may have been an enjoyable game in its time, that time has passed. Many of the FPS and 3D games from that era feel dated, and it really shows here. From the controls, to the graphics, to the general gameplay, the genre has improved leaps and bounds since 2000. While there's some enjoyment to be had for big time Alien fans or those that played this in the past and are feeling nostalgic, I'd recommend most people to stay away.

Grade: C-

reviewText:
Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is an example of how to do First-Person-Shooters right. The fast gameplay requires more skill and focus than most modern First-Person-Shooters. Instead of trying to level up your character to get OP weapons, most weapons have a legitimate purpose, and most of them don't feel too overpowered (except Disc, Pred Pistol, Skeeter, and Sadar. Not to forget Mines). Instead of grinding to get perks to power yourself up, Aliens versus Predator requires skill from the start.

Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 [Which I will be calling 'AvP' through out the rest of this review] allows the player to take control of three species, Aliens, Predators, or the human Marines. Each have their advantages and disadvantages.

The Alien is a melee only species, a hurtful disadvantage, but is patched up by the speed and wallcrawling ability that the Aliens have. Aliens also can smell the scents of other beings, allowing it to see its victims in the dark. The Alien regains health by headbiting Predators and Humans, you can do this on both the living and the dead. Obviously headbiting live beings is harder than dead ones, but gains back more health.

The Predator is a mix of Melee and ranged weapons, the majority of his weapons, Medicomp, and cloak are powered by 'Field Charge'. This will auto-recharge if you are not using anything that uses charge, or you can find field-charge items around the map which will give you full energy. The only weapons that don't use energy are the Wristblades, and Disc (Unless you use the recall ability, that will use a small amount of energy), as well as the Speargun. But this uses ammo, which only replenishes upon death. The Predator can heal using his Medicomp, this will use a large amount of energy, but puts you back to full health everytime (TIP: Secondary fire of Medicomp will put out fires). In some of the bonus levels the Predator gains a new gadget, the grappling hook, which can pull him to higher heights. The Predator also has three vision modes, which can help him spot enemies. The first vision mode can help spot humans, the second aliens, and the third other Predators and field-charges (Of course you have the default normal vision).

The Marine is a ranged only species, guns guns and more guns. The Marine replenishes health with medkits, found about through-out levels. Armor, which can protect against Alien acid and absorbs small amounts of damage. The Marine has a Motion Tracker, if anything moves, a small dot and a beep sound will appear on it. But it isn't always reliable, if ANYTHING moves it will beep. In some of the bonus levels the Marines get a jetpack, allowing them to fly to spaaaaace! In multiplayer Marines can select a specialist sub-class, this will allow them to pick from any of the weapons in the game (unless game host restricted it), and you will always spawn with the selected weapon, but you can only use that weapon (and the pistol).

Each species can unlock bonus missions after you complete the main game, (you will unlock more if you beat it on a higher difficulty) these levels are the levels from other species singleplayer, for example: You can unlock a backwards version of the Predator's first level as Marine if you beat the Marine SP on Director's cut [Hard]. Pretty cool!

Not to forget, you can unlock cheat options in the game by completing certain objectives through-out the levels. These can be things like slow-mo whenever you are near enemies. Or unlimited speargun ammo and more spears per shot as Predator.

The music will change depending on what species you are playing as, Predator will recall images of the jungle, Marines have a very militaristic beat, while Aliens have a slow and creepy tone. The music really sets the tone well, but I wouldn't find myself listening to it outside the game.

The Multiplayer is where this game shines most. Fast gameplay and the different play-styles of each species make for very fun and memorable experience. This is one of the fastest games ever, you will die, fast, and a lot. It is extremly well balanced, and I almost never feel like a player is winning because of the species they are playing as. But, unfortunatly, this game has a small player base, so at times you may not be able to find a game. Because of this the community doesn't play competitively (most of the time), anymore. Servers will also usually have a small amount of players, 8-player games are kinda rare, but when they happen, it is sooooo fun!

Aliens versus Predator Classic 2000 is easily one of the fastest games, and one of the best, ever made.

You would be doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game!

This is a good game despite it's age. Why? Because it has something to offer that not a single game that not even the sequels got right. Three distinctive characters to play as with different play styles that are done particularly well in their own aspects. Levels that are short yet sweet like a mission from Metal Slug and not feeling bloated like Skyrim where most of the content is crap.

Let's start off with the marine campaign. You play as a Colonial Marine who wakes up from a bad dream and finds out Xenomorphs are loose aboard the research station on LV-426. The story is you do menial tasks to get rid of those pesky xenos. But the story isn't the attraction to this game anyway. The game mechanics are the attraction. Each level was designed with speed running and fast paced game action in mind. Your character moves very fast (all three of them do). Your weapon arsenal is powerful for the Marine and Predator. The combat is sudden because enemies are procedurally generated in different positions throughout levels and infinitely to encourage you to keep going and not bringing the game to a halt. This means you'll never find this game to be a slog in it's pacing. There's no story sequences that bring the game to halt whatsoever. The means of telling the story is completely optional for you to listen to. While playing as the marine you'll realize you can't manually reload your weapons. This actually doesn't hinder the game as one would think it would. As your weapons contain so much firepower and reload time is so quick it will be after an engagement. Not during. If it is during one you can use your agility to avoid attacks. Still keeping the pacing up. The levels themselves are open to exploration. But the drawback to them is they can be very maze like sometimes. An obvious flaw to a good game.

But the sequences themselves are so cool you'll keep wanting to play. In Episode III in the marine campaign, I found myself encountering regular Xenomorphs and face huggers. The face huggers themselves are quite the surprise. I was torching 4 Xenos that cornered me in a hall with my flamethrower. All of them popping like water balloons filled with acid as it rains all over the steel corridors. But I see I have one more enemy near me on my radar. I toss a flare and the hall lights up. And out a facehugger pounces around the corner and cling to my face! The neat thing about this was it wasn't scripted at all. Scenarios like these provide replay value beyond the speed running to play. Something that the sequels sorely missed.

The predator himself plays like a pseudo stealth action game character at speed running with powerful weapons and a focus on melee attacks too. The first levels you'll find yourself uppercutting marines with your claws while cloaked as they dim wittily walk around in dark areas filled with more than just Xenos and bunny hopping around corridors and over cliffs. Against Xenos you'll find yourself popping off their body limbs with your claws, accurately predicting their movements do you pin them against walls with your spear gun, or just blasting them away your shoulder cannon in a super cool vision mode just like the movies!

Thing is about killing the Xenos as either Marine or   Predator. You have to be somewhat tactical about killing them. They'll still spray acid fluids about after death. As a marine it will chew away your armor and health like you wouldn't believe. It'll kill you as fast as you can kill them when you get cornered and blast them away with your minigun. Killing Xenos with your claws as a predator has to be quick and efficient. You charge up, let them come to you, and let it loose and step away.

Playing as the Xenomorph reduces you to melee attacks and being able to climb anything. Simple as it is. It really works. The FOV is bigger so you can see well. Sticking to walls and wall jumping is easy as hit the CTRL button when landing. Holding it if you want to stay on that surface. You can move just as easy when holding it too! You are reduced to claws, biting enemy heads which does a lot of damage and gives you health, and a tail charge attack. You must use stealth and hit and run tactics to take out enemies. You'll be crawling on ceilings, leaping fifty feet, and delivering a timed tail attack to stab right through some jarhead's skull. It's the weakest of the three. But still manages to be good fun.

Despite all this. This game has a serious flaw that needs to be brought up. The level design is highly unintuitive. It will be very maze like for first time players and very hard to spot important mission progressions in the dark environments. Some parts of the levels are copy pasted too much. You'll see the same room and halls like five times. But thankfully the linearity keeps from being like Doom 2's crap levels yet still providing opportunities for exploration.

But despite that flaw. Once you get the levels down you'll get fast paced action with dynamic events and seriously immersive characters to play as. This game is easily a 4/5 game back then and now. Still worth playing even if you aren't a Alien (or Predator) fan. Becuse you won't experience anything in its entirety again or as good.

This is a good game despite it's age. Why? Because it has something to offer that not a single game that not even the sequels got right. Three distinctive characters to play as with different play styles that are done particularly well in their own aspects. Levels that are short yet sweet like a mission from Metal Slug and not feeling bloated like Skyrim where most of the content is crap.

Let's start off with the marine campaign. You play as a Colonial Marine who wakes up from a bad dream and finds out Xenomorphs are loose aboard the research station on LV-426. The story is you do menial tasks to get rid of those pesky xenos. But the story isn't the attraction to this game anyway. The game mechanics are the attraction. Each level was designed with speed running and fast paced game action in mind. Your character moves very fast (all three of them do). Your weapon arsenal is powerful for the Marine and Predator. The combat is sudden because enemies are procedurally generated in different positions throughout levels and infinitely to encourage you to keep going and not bringing the game to a halt. This means you'll never find this game to be a slog in it's pacing. There's no story sequences that bring the game to halt whatsoever. The means of telling the story is completely optional for you to listen to. While playing as the marine you'll realize you can't manually reload your weapons. This actually doesn't hinder the game as one would think it would. As your weapons contain so much firepower and reload time is so quick it will be after an engagement. Not during. If it is during one you can use your agility to avoid attacks. Still keeping the pacing up. The levels themselves are open to exploration. But the drawback to them is they can be very maze like sometimes. An obvious flaw to a good game.

But the sequences themselves are so cool you'll keep wanting to play. In Episode III in the marine campaign, I found myself encountering regular Xenomorphs and face huggers. The face huggers themselves are quite the surprise. I was torching 4 Xenos that cornered me in a hall with my flamethrower. All of them popping like water balloons filled with acid as it rains all over the steel corridors. But I see I have one more enemy near me on my radar. I toss a flare and the hall lights up. And out a facehugger pounces around the corner and cling to my face! The neat thing about this was it wasn't scripted at all. Scenarios like these provide replay value beyond the speed running to play. Something that the sequels sorely missed.

The predator himself plays like a pseudo stealth action game character at speed running with powerful weapons and a focus on melee attacks too. The first levels you'll find yourself uppercutting marines with your claws while cloaked as they dim wittily walk around in dark areas filled with more than just Xenos and bunny hopping around corridors and over cliffs. Against Xenos you'll find yourself popping off their body limbs with your claws, accurately predicting their movements do you pin them against walls with your spear gun, or just blasting them away your shoulder cannon in a super cool vision mode just like the movies!

Thing is about killing the Xenos as either Marine or   Predator. You have to be somewhat tactical about killing them. They'll still spray acid fluids about after death. As a marine it will chew away your armor and health like you wouldn't believe. It'll kill you as fast as you can kill them when you get cornered and blast them away with your minigun. Wow. 15 years, and this thing still has charm and oodles of enjoyment waiting to be discovered.

The multiplayer is still supported, and that impresses and pleases me, and to be quite honest, that's where the real value of the game rests; in the multiplayer. The singleplayer had no real value or hook to it, and the levels are confusing as hell to navigate through. Good if you're one of those gamers that enjoys plenty of puzzles and searching, but a real pain for those who are fans of Aliens vs. Predator, and the high-speed combat that the games offer.

Gameplay wise, this thing does sort of leave a lot to be desired, principally through Marine gameplay. Granted, recent Aliens games have kind of buffed up the Colonial Marines, but in this game, there is one critical feature that is noticably absent: the ability to reload. Couple that with gun jams (which I would actually enjoy a lot if the reload mechanic wasn't a fantasy in this game) and a fairly weakened Marine starting rifle, and you have a species whose only real option is to either spam pulse rifle grenades or power weapons (and there are copious amounts of power weapons in this, going far beyond the film arsenals).

The Aliens and Predators, like the Marines, pretty much surf through the maps at ludicrous speed, which is literally where the high-speed combat statement comes from. The Predator does sort of suffer from Marine damage issues - their main weapons, the wristblades, are as weak as the Alien's light attacks, so as a result you'll probably encounted a lot of players either sprinting around firing spearguns or poising their tails to lash out and instakill you.

If you're a fanatic for fast-paced, hyperactive games that will bring you up on your feet and have you laughing for hours, this is a must. It's fairly affordable, and while it is by no means the best Aliens game, it's where it belongs and will give you tons of enjoyment, laughs and jump-scares.

AVP Classic is quite a primitive game, even for FPS' of its time - you have some weapons and some poorly-lit hallways, and you must traverse said hallways using said weapons to kill your attackers, completing some minor objectives to open the path to the end. Simple as that. Half-Life came out a year or so before this, and unlike many games that then followed, AVP aschews almost all pretence of a narrative. In this way it feels like a darker, scarier Doom. It is a literal run-and-gun game, and incomparible to almost anything contemporary, even to it's own sequel, which is a vastly different experience.

AVP is also brutally difficult, and requires the player to have fast reflexes while also keep their wits about them as the blaze through the corridors. Kill anything that moves, and kill it quick. This makes for a tense and frenetic game, and facehuggers whipping out of no-where to one-hit-kill me always makes me jump.

This won't be everyone's cup of tea, especially if you're migrating backwards from AVP2, hoping for more of the same. But with the few tools at its disposal, playing AVP is a uniquely exhilirating experience and rewards a skillful (and lucky) player with the few minutes of well-earned rest at the end of each level before the next one begins.

I recommend this if you have a few bucks to spare and you're after a fast, simple, challenging FPS.

The game itself isn't terrible in the least. It's got good controls and an almost QUAKE style of movement where you can almost outrun the aliens without any serious impact on accuracy. This is very much an early 2000's shooter, and still retains the charm of games of the era while still being appreciable for the modern times.

The problems come about when it comes to the story mode, primarily. The Marine is probably the best character with a wide array of weapons to choose from, very little platforming necessary, and with probably the minimal amount of save scumming required. The predator come second, because again, diverse weapons and limited platforming, but with the bonus of being able to cloak and use genuine stealth tactics appropriate for the early 2000s. But then comes the Alien. The xenomorph is undoubtedly one of the most unplayable characters, and this seems to be a trend among games featuring the Alien because platforming is a huge deal, which can be a problem. When you're a marine or a predator, you can find your way around because you're only limited to the floor. The alien, meanwhile, can go everywhere there's a surface, which means you'll spend a bunch of time crawling on walls and ceilings and ultimately end up lost without a walkthrough. While all the characters necessitate a walkthrough, because this did come from the age when video games hated telling the player things, it gets even worse when you can literally end up lost in the vents for a good thirty minutes going in circles at about 100 miles per hour.

The combat is pretty solid for all characters. Enemies become easily detatched from their limbs, flames and explosions are catastrophic, and when you hit some dude with lazer forged wristblades he's not gonna have a good time. The marine is exclusively ranged, the alien is exclusively melee, and the predator contains a mix of the two.

The graphics are actually pretty nice for a game made in 2000. Imagine Oblivion or Fallout 3 but with super primitive articulation. The textures can be a bit of a problem, as they never seem to mask when a wall or a floor is outright flat, making it especially hard to find a switch that just blends into the graphic.

All in all, I'd recommend checking a playthrough of the game played in Skirmish mode before actually buying it. It'd be good to get on sale to try out, as it stands on the combat alone, but if you're going to do any of the stories make sure to have a walkthrough available because one can not be faulted for getting stuck in the story.
